column3: A discrete physical fragment or portion removed from the painting for study or conservation.

This model defines the Sample (S13) as a discrete physical fragment removed from a heritage object for study. It brings together identification, classification, and contextual data, linking each sample to its source object, the sampling event, and any subsequent analytical or modification events. Ownership, custody, and storage are documented to support traceability, while descriptive and measurement links ensure that both qualitative and quantitative observations remain connected to their physical origin.
The event during which the sample was physically removed from its source object.
The artwork or object from which the sample originated.
The artwork or object from which the sample originated.
The physical place where the sample is currently housed or permanently stored.
The legal owner of the sample.
The institution responsible for the care, storage, or management of the physical sample.
Any document, note, report, or publication describing or relating to the sample.
An event in which one or more quantitative properties of the sample were measured.
An event in which qualitative or visual properties of the sample were examined.
An event that altered the sample after its initial removal, such as preparation, embedding, or coating.
For samples not defined will a fully resolvable PID like an IGSN the prefered ID is likely to be the same as or based on the E41: Sample Label/No/ID
Automatic: Preferred Painting ID - Sample Label
A locally assigned identifier or code used by the institution responsible for managing the physical sample.
A locally assigned identifier or code used by the institution responsible for managing the physical sample by which the sample may be known in external systems, publications, or legacy records.
A human-readable name or number used to identify the sample in documentation or images, typically visible on labels or slides.

Classification of the physical nature of the sample. terms could include concepts like: scraping, micro-scraping, single fragment, micro-fragment, stratigraphic paint flake, surface coating flake, collection of fragments, bulk sample, powdered sample, thin film / smear, binding medium sample.

Classification of how the sample has been organised or modified for storage or examination. terms could include concepts like: unmounted flake, resin-embedded block, polished cross-section, carbon-coated cross-section, gold-coated cross-section, dispersion, thin section, microtome thin section, KBr pellet, diamond cell / compression cell, SEM stub mount, grain mount, filter mount, mATR mount.
Keywords or classification terms (e.g., class, technique, composition).

Dimensions or size class of the sample, controlled list:
micro-sample (< 0.01 m),
small-sample (0.01 – 0.1 m),
medium-sample (0.1 – 0.3 m),
large-sample (0.3 – 1.0 m),
very-large-fragment (> 1.0 m)

Classification of how well the sample has been preserved, or if it has been damaged etc. terms could include concepts like: stable / intact, damaged, diminished, partially consumed, consumed, exhausted, destroyed, altered by preparation, altered by analysis, contaminated, lost, archived, pending preparation.
